info: 'おかあさん' is the polite way to refer to someone's mother.
It can be used to refer to your own mother in a polite context or someone else's mother.
In informal contexts, you might hear it as 'かあさん'.
'おとうさん' is the polite way to refer to someone's father.
It can be used to refer to your own father in a polite context or someone else's father.
In informal contexts, you might hear it as 'とうさん'.
'おねえさん' is the polite way to refer to someone's older sister.
It can be used to refer to your own older sister in a polite context or someone else's older sister.
In informal contexts, you might hear 'ねえさん'.
'おにいさん' is the polite way to refer to someone's older brother.
It can be used to refer to your own older brother in a polite context or someone else's older brother.
In informal contexts, you might hear 'にいさん'.
'いもうと' refers to a younger sister.
It is a term used without a polite prefix.
For someone else's younger sister, you would say 'いもうとさん'.
'おとうと' refers to a younger brother.
It is a term used without a polite prefix.
For someone else's younger brother, you would say 'おとうとさん'.
'おじいさん' is the polite way to refer to someone's grandfather.
It can be used to refer to your own grandfather in a polite context or someone else's grandfather.
In informal contexts, you might hear 'じいさん' or 'おじいちゃん'.
'おばあさん' is the polite way to refer to someone's grandmother.
It can be used to refer to your own grandmother in a polite context or someone else's grandmother.
In informal contexts, you might hear 'ばあさん' or 'おばあちゃん'.
'おばさん' is the polite way to refer to someone's aunt.
It can be used to refer to your own aunt in a polite context or someone else's aunt.
In informal contexts, you might hear 'ばさん' or 'おばちゃん'.
'おじさん' is the polite way to refer to someone's uncle.
It can be used to refer to your own uncle in a polite context or someone else's uncle.
In informal contexts, you might hear 'じさん' or 'おじちゃん'.
'だいがく' refers to a college or university.
It is used to describe institutions of higher education.
It can also be part of compound words, such as 'だいがくせい' (college student).
'こうこう' refers to high school.
It is the stage of education before college.
Students in high school are referred to as 'こうこうせい'.
'がくせい' is a general term for student.
It can be used to refer to students of all educational levels.
'だいがくせい' refers to a college or university student.
It combines 'だいがく' (college) and 'せい' (student).
It is commonly used to identify someone's educational status.
'りゅうがくせい' refers to an international student or foreign exchange student.
It combines 'りゅう' (to stay) and 'がくせい' (student).
It is used to describe students who study abroad.
'～ねんせい' is a suffix used to indicate the grade or year of a student.
For example, 'さんねんせい' means 'third-year student'.
'いちねんせい' means 'first-year student'.
It combines 'いち' (one) and 'ねんせい' (year student).
It is commonly used to describe students in their first year of study.
'せんこう' refers to a field of study or major in college.
It is used to describe the primary subject area a student is studying.
'わたし' is the standard way to say 'I' or 'me' in Japanese.
It is gender-neutral and can be used in both formal and informal contexts.
Men could use 'ぼく' instead, and might even prefer 'おれ' in informal settings.
'ともだち' means 'friend' in Japanese.
It can refer to both male and female friends.
The term does not indicate the level of closeness of the friendship.
'～さん' is a polite title used after someone's name.
It is similar to Mr., Mrs., or Ms. in English.
It can be used with both first and last names, but in more formal or unfamiliar contexts, it is common to use it with last names.

You should refer to everyone with '～さん' until you are told otherwise, as it ensures politeness and respect, which is a fundamental aspect of Japanese culture and differs significantly from Western norms.
NEVER use 'さん' when referring to yourself. It is strictly used to address or refer to others. Using ～さん for oneself is considered overly self-important and is culturally inappropriate.
'～じん' is a suffix used to indicate nationality or ethnicity.
For example, 'にほんじん' means 'Japanese people/person'.
It is commonly used to describe the people of a particular country.
It combines 'にほん' (Japan) and 'じん' (people).
'ばんごう' means 'number'.
It is used for phone numbers, room numbers, and other numerical identifiers.
For example, 'でんわばんごう' means 'phone number'.
'なまえ' means 'name'.
It can refer to both first names and last names.
For example, 'おなまえは？' means 'What is your name?'.
'みんな' means 'everyone' or 'all' in Japanese.
It is used to refer to a group of people inclusively.
'なん' and 'なに' both mean 'what'.
'なん' is used before counters and 'なに' is used in other contexts.
For example, 'なんですか？' means 'What is it?' and 'なにをしますか？' means 'What will you do?'.
'あのう' is a filler word used to pause or hesitate in speech.
It is similar to 'um' or 'uh' in English.
It is often used when the speaker is thinking or trying to get someone's attention politely.
'はい' means 'yes' in Japanese.
It can also be used to show agreement or acknowledgment.
In some contexts, it can mean 'here' or 'present' when responding to a roll call.
'そうです' means 'That's right' or 'It is so'.
It is used to confirm information or agree with a statement.
'そうですか' means 'I see' or 'Is that so?'.
It is used to show understanding or surprise.
In Japanese culture, showing active listening and engagement is crucial for building rapport and trust.
Japanese speakers often use this phrase to show that they are listening and engaged in the conversation.
Japanese speakers frequently use interjections like 'そうですか,' 'うん,' 'はい,' 'へえ,' and 'なるほど' to show they are listening. These even have their own name—'aizuchi' and serve as verbal nods.
Aizuchi are used more often in Japanese than in English, reflecting a higher level of active listening and engagement. Try to use them in your own conversations
It is used to refer to medical professionals who diagnose and treat illnesses.
The polite term 'おいしゃさん' (oishasan) is often used, especially by children.
It is used to describe someone who works for a company.
The term combines 'かいしゃ' (company) and 'いん' (member).
It refers to healthcare professionals who care for patients and assist doctors.
The term is gender-neutral, although 'かんごふ' (kangofu) is sometimes used specifically for female nurses.
It combines 'こうこう' (high school) and 'せい' (student).
High school in Japan typically includes grades 10 through 12.
It refers to someone who manages the household and takes care of the family.
The term can also apply to men who stay at home, although 'しゅふ' is traditionally used for women.
It combines 'だいがく' (university) with 'いん' (graduate school) and 'せい' (student).
It refers to students pursuing advanced degrees beyond a bachelor's.
It refers to legal professionals who represent clients in court and provide legal advice.
The term combines 'べんご' (defense) and 'し' (professional).

furigana: アジア[あしあ]けんきゅう
info: It refers to the academic field focusing on the study of Asian cultures, languages, history, and societies.
The term combines 'アジア' (Asia)—written in Katakana—and 'けんきゅう' (research/study).
It refers to the social science that studies the production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services.
The term is commonly used in academic and professional contexts.
It refers to the application of scientific and mathematical principles to design, build, and maintain structures, machines, and systems.
The term is commonly used in academic and professional contexts.
It refers to the study of interactions between countries and the roles of sovereign states, intergovernmental organizations, non-governmental organizations, and multinational corporations.
The term combines 'こくさい' (international) and 'かんけい' (relations).

furigana: コンピューター[こんぴゅうたあ
info: 'コンピューター' (written in Katakana) is an English loan word that sounds like 'computer', and has the same meaning.
It refers to the activities, actions, and policies used to gain and hold power in a government or to influence government decisions.
The term is used in academic, professional, and everyday contexts.
It refers to the scientific study of life and living organisms, including their structure, function, growth, evolution, and distribution.
The term combines 'せいぶつ' (living things) and 'がく' (study).
'ビジネス' (written in Katakana) is an English loan word that sounds like 'business' and also has the same meaning.
It refers to written works, especially those considered of superior or lasting artistic merit.
The term is used in academic and literary contexts.
It refers to the study of past events, particularly in human affairs.
The term is used in academic, educational, and everyday contexts.
'いま' means 'now' or 'right now' in Japanese.
It is commonly used in daily conversations to indicate the present time.
'ごぜん' is used to refer to the morning or A.M. hours.
It is typically used with numbers to specify times in the morning.
'ごご' means 'afternoon' or 'P.M.' in Japanese.
It is used with numbers to specify times in the afternoon or evening.
'～じ' is used to indicate the hour on the clock in Japanese.
It is added after numbers to denote specific hours.
'いちじ' means 'one o'clock' or '1:00' in Japanese.
It combines 'いち' (one) with 'じ' (o'clock) to specify the time.
'はん' means 'half' in Japanese and is used to indicate half past the hour.
It can be combined with an hour to specify the time.
'にじはん' means 'half past two' or '2:30' in Japanese.
It combines 'にじ' (two o'clock) with 'はん' (half) to specify the time.
'にほん' is the Japanese word for 'Japan'.
It can also be pronounced as 'にっぽん', especially in formal or official contexts.
'アメリカ' (Amerika) is the Japanese word for 'America' or the 'USA'.
It is written in katakana, which is used for foreign words.
'イギリス' (Igirisu) can refer to the United Kingdom (UK), Britain, or England in everyday use.
It is a katakana word derived from the Portuguese word for 'English'.
'オーストラリア' (Ōsutoraria) is the Japanese word for 'Australia'.
Like other country names, it is written in katakana.
'かんこく' means 'Korea' or 'South Korea' in Japanese.
It specifically refers to the Republic of Korea, as opposed to North Korea ('きたちょうせん').
'カナダ' (Kanada) is the Japanese word for 'Canada'.
It is written in katakana, following the convention for foreign country names.
'ちゅうごく' means 'China' in Japanese.
It is the standard term used to refer to the People's Republic of China.
'インド' (Indo) is the Japanese word for 'India'.
It is written in katakana, used for foreign country names.
'エジプト' (Ejiputo) is the Japanese word for 'Egypt'.
It follows the katakana script convention for foreign place names.
'フィリピン' (Firipin) is the Japanese word for 'Philippines'.
It is written in katakana as is common for foreign country names.
